Nonvitamin, nonmineral, and natural items are the most often utilized complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) therapy in adults. Other therapies that have gained popularity include deep breathing techniques, meditation, massage therapy, and yoga (Rhee et al. 897). Complementary or integrative therapies are frequently used in conjunction with mainstream Western medicine and are viewed as holistic in nature. Additionally, they are considered to be holistic in nature. Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), according to a 2009 report from the Institute of Medicine, employs treatment methods that are not widely used in Western medicine. According to a study, meditation and religion, as well as natural remedies and hands-on therapies ranging from chiropractic to mind/body methods, are all common self-healing techniques. When possible and if the patient indicates that they have benefited from them, such therapies should be incorporated into the patient's overall care. The National Institutes of Health's National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine has been renamed the National Center for Complementary and Integrative Medicine. This might be interpreted as a means of encouraging further research into alternative medicines, as well as a more seamless integration of them into traditional health care.
